author: wcax.com
title: Latest Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont news, sports, business and entertainment
text:
MAINE:
MAINE CHEESE DAY
Maine's growing cheese business invites public for open day
MONROE, Maine (AP) - Maine cheese makers are inviting the public to check out one of the state's fastest growing industries during Open Creamery Day.
The Maine Cheese Guild is hosting the event on Sunday until 3 p.m. The creameries that are participating in the event are located in southern, central and mid-coast Maine.
Visitors will be able to check out the creameries, meet the owners and see the animals. Participants include Breakwater Vineyards in Owls Head, Silver Moon Creamery at Smiling Hill Farm in Westbrook and Appleton Creamery in Appleton.
The number of retail cheesemakers in the state has doubled from 40 in 2010 to 80 this year.
PEDESTRIANS STRUCK-PORTLAND
Maine police say SUV hits woman, child in Portland
PORTLAND, Maine (AP) - Maine police say a woman and a 3-yar-old child were struck by an SUV and seriously injured while crossing a Portland street.
Authorities say the accident occurred at about 8 p.m. on Auburn Street.
The Portland Press Herald reports that the SUV was driven by a 55-year-old man who police have not named.
The child and 34-year-old woman were taken to Maine Medical Center. Police say they are still trying to determine whether the two are related.
Authorities say speed does not appear to have been a factor. No charges were filed Saturday and the investigation is continuing.
FARMERS MARKET GRANTS
Maine Federation of Farmers' Markets to get $348K from feds
PITTSFIELD, Maine (AP) - The Maine Federation of Farmers' Markets will receive more than $348,000 in federal funds for its work around the state.
The money is coming in the form of two grants. One is from the United States Department of Agriculture and will provide $249,600 to increase access at farmers market for people who use food stamps.
The other grant is also from the USDA and includes money for a two-year marketing campaign. It also includes the development of a Farmers' Market Snapshot Week event to collect data and information about Maine's farmers markets.
The money is part of $35 million in funding announced by federal Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack this month. The money is from four grant programs and will support local and regional food systems such as farmers markets.
MAINE-ALBANY (NY)
Collins, Belcher combine to lead Maine over Albany 39-7
ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) - Dan Collins and Drew Belcher combined for four touchdowns, leading Maine to a 39-7 win over Albany on Saturday.
Collins led Maine (2-3, 2-1 Colonial) on three first-quarter touchdown drives, building a 20-0 lead. Belcher played mostly mop-up duty, throwing touchdown passes in the third and fourth quarter to Micah Wright and Jaleel Reed, respectively. Collins was 21 of 28 for 208 yards with a rushing and passing touchdown, and Belcher was 7 of 8 for 75 yards.
D.J. Crook's 6-yard touchdown pass to Zee Roberson got Albany (2-4, 1-2) on the scoreboard with less than three minutes left in the second quarter. Crook was 17 of 30 for 167 yards and two interceptions and Roberson had 102 yards on nine catches.
Albany, which had been averaging over 120 yards rushing per game, was held to 5 yards on 22 carries. Maine had 185 yards on 33 carries.
NEW HAMPSHIRE:
GOP 2016-GRAHAM
McCain continues to tout Graham in New Hampshire
HUDSON, N.H. (AP) - John McCain and Lindsey Graham are wrapping up another trip to New Hampshire to boost Graham's presidential bid with a house party at the home of New Hampshire House Speaker Shawn Jasper.
The house party concludes a three-day, 10-stop trip by Graham, a South Carolina senator, and McCain, an Arizona senator and two-time New Hampshire primary winner. Graham is struggling to gain traction among a crowded Republican primary field despite the support from McCain, who's traveled to the state to campaign alongside Graham several times.
The weekend included stops at a Manchester bingo hall and diner, the Salem American Legion and the Raymond and Pelham VFW. Graham is focusing his campaign on national security issues. The two also campaigned in Rochester, Canterbury and Goffstown.
FOOTRACE FOR THE FALLEN
New Hampshire 5K race to honor fallen officers, aid charity
MANCHESTER, N.H. (AP) - The Manchester Police Department is sponsoring its 9th annual Footrace for the Fallen 5K to honor officers who lost their lives in the line of duty.
The event was planned for Sunday morning in New Hampshire's largest city.
Organizers expect a record number of runners this year for a race that typically draws more than 800 participants.
All proceeds benefit the Manchester Police Athletic League.
Gov. Maggie Hassan will speak before the race at 9:30 a.m. at the starting line at the Manchester Police Department headquarters. Her opponent in the U.S. Senate race - incumbent Kelly Ayotte - is running in the race.
DARTMOUTH-DONATION
Dartmouth alum offers $5 million matching gift for lodge
HANOVER, N.H. (AP) - A Dartmouth alumnus and his family are offering to match up to $5 million toward rebuilding the college's 77-year-old lodge in the White Mountains.
The Moosilauke Ravine Lodge about 45 miles northeast of Hanover in Warren was built in 1938. It is the end destination of Dartmouth's First-Year Trips program, hosting more than 90 percent of every incoming class, and is used for orientation programs for the college's medical and business schools.
George "Skip" Battle, a 1966 graduate, will match all contributions toward the rebuilding project made between now and June 30 up to $5 million. The project is expected to cost $17 million, with construction beginning next September.
Battle is a senior fellow at the Aspen Institute and former CEO of Ask.com.
COMMEMORATIVE PLAQUE-FLOOD
Plaque in Alstead honors commemorates flood deaths, damages
ALSTEAD, N.H. (AP) - Residents of Alstead, New Hampshire, gathered to dedicate a plaque honoring the deaths, damages and recovery efforts on the 10th anniversary of the 2005 flood.
The plaque is built into a stone on the banks of the Cold River, which raged and took out homes, vehicles, roads and bridges a decade ago.
Alstead and the nearby towns of Langdon and Walpole were among the hardest hit when rain drenched the state. The U.S. Geological Survey reports that at least seven inches of rain fell in a 30-hour period. Seven people died - four of them in Alstead - and homes and property were destroyed.
WMUR-TV reports that Alstead residents raised the $1,000 for the plaque with donations of $20.05 each - an amount representing the year of the flood.
VERMONT:
BURGLARY ARREST-REPEAT OFFENDER
Vermont police arrest man with lengthy criminal record
BURLINGTON, Vt. (AP) - Vermont police have charged a 45-year-old fugitive with a lengthy criminal record with escape and several commercial burglaries in Burlington.
Authorities say 45-year-old Lance Mason of Burlington was arrested after patrons of a St. Paul Street restaurant reported a pocketbook and knapsack had been stolen from hooks inside the restaurant Saturday night.
Police say Mason, who had an outstanding warrant for escape for removing his GPS monitoring bracelet in August, was located nearby and in possession of some of the stolen articles.
He was charged with grand larceny in connection with the Saturday thefts and with burglaries at two businesses in late September.
Police say Mason's criminal record includes 17 misdemeanor convictions and 19 felony convictions.
He is due in court Tuesday. It was not immediately known whether he has a lawyer.
WILDLIFE PLAN
Vermont Fish and Wildlife seeking opinions on strategic plan
MONTPELIER, Vt. (AP) - The Vermont Department of Fish and Wildlife is seeking public input on a draft 10-year, strategic plan that calls for a continued focus on habitat conservation and the most effective strategies for protecting wildlife.
The Wildlife Action Plan also calls for boosting Vermont's economy and quality of life and it emphasizes collaboration and partnership with agencies, municipalities, and conservation organizations.
The department says the goal of the plan is to keep common species common while promoting additional conservation actions for less common species so they don't slip toward threatened or endangered status.
Newer challenges include climate change, emerging diseases such as white-nose syndrome in bats, and additional threats to bees and butterflies.
The plan can be found on the department's website.
The comment period is open until Nov. 8.
VERMONT-TRAIN-DERAILMENT
State Police: Locomotive from train derailment is removed
NORTHFIELD, Vt. (AP) - Vermont State Police say the locomotive of a train that derailed earlier this week in Northfield has been removed and nearby roads have been reopened.
The work took several hours on Saturday.
The area and intersections of Vermont Routes 12 and 12A and Wall Street were closed.
A passenger train headed from Vermont to Washington derailed Monday when it hit rocks that had fallen onto the track from a ledge. Seven people were injured. Amtrak says everyone who was injured was released from the hospital the following day.
WATERSHED GRANTS
Grants available to help protect, restore watersheds
MONTPELIER, Vt. (AP) - A total of $70,000 in grants is available to municipalities, local governmental agencies, non-profit organizations and citizen groups for projects that help to protect and restore Vermont's watersheds.
Rick Hopkins of the Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation says many types of projects are eligible, including those that protect or restore water quality, shorelines or fish and wildlife habitats.
Grants are available in three categories: education and outreach; planning, assessment, inventory, monitoring; and on-the-ground implementation.
The Vermont Watershed Grants Program is a joint project of DEC and the Fish and Wildlife Department.
The program, funded by the sale of conservation license plates, has funded 351 watershed projects around the state in 1998.
The application deadline is Nov. 20.
PEOPLE-RANDY QUAID
Quaid taken into custody in Vermont trying to cross border
HIGHGATE, Vt. (AP) - Vermont State Police say actor Randy Quaid has been taken into custody while trying to cross from Canada into the United States.
State Police say the "Independence Day" actor was detained by troopers at the Highgate Springs port of entry on Friday night, days after Canadian officials said he would be deported. Quaid is wanted in Santa Barbara, California, to face felony vandalism charges filed in 2010 after he and his wife, Evi, were found squatting in a guesthouse of a home they previously owned.
The pair skipped several court appearances and went to Canada, where Evi Quaid was granted citizenship. Randy Quaid's bid to gain permanent residency was denied.
The 65-year-old Quaid told The Associated Press earlier this week that he wanted to resolve his legal troubles in California.
